","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1566311155702,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":true,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"TP-2","entityId":"2-2","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"TP"},{"name":"summary","value":"Support internal protected visibility"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"root"},{"name":"created","value":"1563796681420"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"2"},{"name":"description","value":"

Big libraries like kotlinx.couroutines would greatly benefit from internal protected visibility that restricts access only to inheriting classes in the same module. The reason is that the library might define some auxiliary class like Base with a bunch protected methods that have final override in some user-visible open class Derived, which is open by itself. However, we don't want user-defined classes that override Derived to be able to access those protected method.

The implementation of internal protected could have used the same java-name mangling approach that is used by internal to reduce the likelyhood of abuse of those methods from Java code.

class A{
fun f1(){
println("A.f1")
}
}

class B(val a: A)
fun B.myA(func: A.()->Unit){
a.func()
}

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
val b = B(A())
with(b) {
// case 1
myA {
<caret>f1() // Alt+Enter: 2 intentions available: "Add explicit 'this'" and "Move lambda argument into parentheses"
}
// case 2
myA ({
<caret>f1() // Alt+Enter: here 3 intentions available: "Add explicit 'this'", "Move lambda argument out of parentheses" and "Convert lambda to reference"
})
}
}
Intention "Convert lambda to reference" should be available in the case 1 too.

class A{
fun f1(){
println("A.f1")
}
}

fun myA(func: A.()->Unit){
A().func()
}

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
// case 1
myA {
f1() // no offer to convert to reference, but should it be?
}

// case 2
myA {
this.f1() // no offer to convert to reference, but should it be?
}

// Probably in both cases the expected result is:
myA (A::f1) // Here "Convert reference to lambda" is available and a result is a case 1
}

// You can reproduce it with `emptyArray()` if `giveType()` looks like "not a real case".
fun <T> giveType(): T? = null
fun addType4(p = giveType()) {}
fun addType4v(vararg p = giveType()) {}

Check quick fixes for non-vararg p : "Specify type explicitly" is not suggested. Seems that could be?

interface Alarm {
    fun ringTheBell(times: Int) {}
}

open class Device {
    open fun ringTheBell(times: Int) {}
}

open class Phone: Device(), Alarm {}
— Phone class will be highlighted with red because it inherits many implementations of ringTheBell function from its immediate superclasses. However, there is no quick fix suggested.

It probably should do something like an example given in Kotlin reference: 
override fun ringTheBell(times: Int) {
    super<Device>.ringTheBell(times)
    super<Alarm>.ringTheBell(times)
}

(Kotlin)
example 1:
simple dfs function
fun dfs(v: Int) {
        for (u in g[v]) {
            if (!used[u]) {
                dfs(u)
            }
        }
}
idea suggests to convert such a code to :
fun dfs(v: Int) {
        g[v].filter { !used[u] }.forEach { dfs(it) }
}
This code is NOT EQUIVALENT and NOT CORRECT actually (used changes after each dfs(u) invocation).

example 2:
this code:
fun main(args: Array<String>) {
loop1@ for (i in 1..10) {
　for (j in 1..10) {
　　if (i*j == 36)
　　　break@loop1
　　}
　}
}
idea converts to:
fun main(args: Array<String>) {
        loop1@ for (i in 1..10) {
            (1..10).filter { it * it == 36 }.forEach { break@loop1 }
        }
}
and it is not compillable since break is called from lambda!

Hope this cases would be soon fixed :)

Sometimes to resolves to function from Tuples.kt
like here:

kotlin
class A
class B 
fun A.to(b: B) = println("$a$b")

fun some(b: B?) { // assume I'd changed type to nullable during editing
  val a = A()
  a.to(b) // Now function resolves to `to` for forming Pair's, not expected 
}

The inspection

Kotlin | Style issues | Can be replaced with function reference

suggests a fix to replace a lambda with a method reference which is not functionally equal:

kotlin
fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  lambda()
  methodReference()
}

fun lambda() {
  val ef = ExecuteFunction { newObject().doStuff() }
  println("execute now")
  ef.execute()
}

fun methodReference() {
  val ef = ExecuteFunction(newObject()::doStuff)
  println("execute now")
  ef.execute()
}

class ExecuteFunction(val function: () -> Unit) {
  
  fun execute() {
    function()
  }
}

fun newObject() = MyObject()

class MyObject {

  init {
    println("Created")
  }

  fun doStuff() {}
}

@Deprecated(message = "...", level = DeprecationLevel.HIDDEN) is used only to maintained binary compatibility with legacy code at JVM and by definition cannot be used in the source (since it is hidden from resolve), so it should not be reported as unused declaration.

Dmitry Jemerov Roman Elizarov What do you think about other deprecation levels? May be all of them should not be reported as unused?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1511865006635,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]},{"id":"27-2555921","author":"elizarov","authorFullName":"Roman Elizarov","issueId":"KT-21462","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"

I frankly don't know. Maybe all of them should not be, indeed.

You can have tests for other kinds of WARNING-deprecated methods in your code-based, so showing them unused does make some sense. While ERROR, just like HIDDEN cannot be referenced from the source, so the same logic applied to ERROR, indeed.

I usually don't leave any tests for deprecated methods, so I would say, for consistency sake, that deprecated methods should never be shown as unused.

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1511867335026,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":true,"replies":[]},{"id":"27-2556025","author":"yole","authorFullName":"Dmitry Jemerov","issueId":"KT-21462","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
No. If I'm not writing a library, and if I have a deprecated function that is no longer used, I definitely want to see it highlighted as an indication that I can delete it. And DeprecationLevel.HIDDEN makes sense only in libraries, so the original request is totally valid.

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1511287931709,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]},{"id":"27-2540047","author":"pannous.1","authorFullName":"pannous","issueId":"KT-21382","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1511294150665,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]},{"id":"27-2540588","author":"yole","authorFullName":"Dmitry Jemerov","issueId":"KT-21382","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Yes, they do. The language changes necessary to make them not do that would introduce far too much complexity for insufficient benefit. A possible solution to this issue with less complexity is to introduce proper bitwise operators, but that's covered by a different issue: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/KT-1440
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1511337538406,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]},{"id":"27-2542336","author":"pannous.1","authorFullName":"pannous","issueId":"KT-21382","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1511369336075,"updated":1511369350945,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]},{"id":"27-2542378","author":"yole","authorFullName":"Dmitry Jemerov","issueId":"KT-21382","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
It is. As I said, these are simply standard library functions called using the infix function call syntax; the compiler doesn't know anything about their semantics.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1511370621200,"updated":1511337538378,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]},{"id":"27-2923412","author":"Andrey.Breslav","authorFullName":"Andrey Breslav","issueId":"KT-21382","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"

(Observation: the example in the issue considers booleans, while using "and" and "or" for booleans makes little sense ("||" and "&&" should always be preferred), a more relevant example would consider bitwise operations.)

  • There's no way we can change "operator precedence" in this case
  • Reporting a warning in such a case makes perfect sense, thanks for the suggestion
  • KT-1440 will help, but it's not done yet

relates to KT-5442

Unfortunately at this stage Kotlin seems unable to adopt saner usage of operators.

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1529927035386,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":true,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"KT-21316","entityId":"25-1772993","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"KT"},{"name":"summary","value":"Performance regression when replacing a for-in-int-range loop with library operations"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Dmitry Petrov"},{"name":"created","value":"1510927835909"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"21316"},{"name":"description","value":"
IDEA reports a weak warning on the following 'for' loop:
fun test(n: Int) {
    for (i in 0 until n) {
        if (i % 3 == 0) println(i)
    }
}
suggesting to replace it with
fun test(n: Int) {
    (0 until n)
            .filter { it % 3 == 0 }
            .forEach { println(it) }
}

While this code might be more "idiomatic" (which is questionable), it is definitely less efficient:
1) an intermediate object is created for 0 until n range and a corresponding iterator;
2) an intermediate container is created in filter, which stores boxed integers.

Either such suggestion should be a regular intention (not a weak warning), and, in the best of the worlds, should have a corresponding reverse intention action,
OR IDEA should not suggest to "pessimise" the code.

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1510930947735,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]}],"tag":[{"value":"android-performance-problem","cssClass":"c21"}]}, {"id":"KT-21314","entityId":"25-1772881","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"KT"},{"name":"summary","value":"Performance regression when replacing a for-each loop with library operations if Java collection class is imported explicitly"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Dmitry Petrov"},{"name":"created","value":"1510922980457"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"21314"},{"name":"description","value":"
import java.util.ArrayList // NB

fun test(strings: List<String>): MutableList<String> {
    val strings2 = ArrayList<String>()
    for (s in strings) { // (*)
        if (s.length > 3) {
            strings2.add(s)
        }
    }
    return strings2
}

IDEA suggests replacing for loop in (*) with filter{}.toMutableList():
import java.util.ArrayList // becomes unused

fun test(strings: List<String>): MutableList<String> {
    val strings2 = strings
            .filter { it.length > 3 }
            .toMutableList() // (**)
    return strings2
}

This code makes an extra copy of resulting list (by explicitly calling toMutableList at (**)).

Note that if java.util.ArrayList is not imported, then everything works good enough: the following code
fun test(strings: List<String>): MutableList<String> {
    val strings2 = ArrayList<String>()
    for (s in strings) {
        if (s.length > 3) {
            strings2.add(s)
        }
    }
    return strings2
}
is transformed to
fun test(strings: List<String>): MutableList<String> {
    val strings2 = ArrayList<String>()
    strings.filterTo(strings2) { it.length > 3 }
    return strings2
}

data class Person(val name: String, val hobbies: List<String>)

fun print(person: Person) {
    val (name) = person
    println(name)

sealed class Trap(val anchor: PsiElement) {
  ...
  class InsideFinally(val finallyBlock: PsiElement): Trap(finallyBlock)
}

Here writing val before finallyBlock makes it a property effectively creating two identical properties finallyBlock and anchor with their getters unnecessarily expanding the object footprint and class file. I suggest to warn in IDE that val could be omitted here (at least if property is not used currently).

For Java 9 source "Java | Java language level migration aids | Java 9 | Replace null checked condition with Objects static method" inspection is suggested, like in the following dummy:
...
    public void check(String p) {
        if (p == null) {
            accept("empty");
        } else {
            accept(p);
        }
    }
    public void accept(String p) {}
...

It transforms this to:
...
    public void check(String p) {
        accept(Objects.requireNonNullElse(p, "empty"));
    }
    public void accept(String p) {}
...

In Kotlin code gotten with conversion of initial code nothing is suggested. Could be.

NB: Maybe Kotlin has better idioms than requireNonNullElse(). Anyway, currently nothing is suggested.

There is "Java | Java language level migration aids | Java 9 | Immutable collection creation can be replaced with collection factory call" inspection. It reports the cases like the following dummy and provides a quick fix:
...
   Collections.unmodifiableSet(new HashSet<>(Arrays.asList("a", "b", "c")));
   Collections.unmodifiableList(new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList("a", "b", "c")));
...

Looks like in Kotlin similar usages are not reported:
...
    Collections.unmodifiableSet(HashSet(Arrays.asList("a", "b", "c")))
    Collections.unmodifiableList(ArrayList(Arrays.asList("a", "b", "c")))
...
Could be reported: by the same inspection or by Kotlin-specific one.

NB: Maybe Kotlin has better idioms than of() method to use in this case. Anyway, currently nothing is suggested.

In the following code: 
fun main(args: Array<String>) {
    delay(1000)
}
— delay will be underlined with red, reporting a warning "Suspend function delay should be called only from a coroutine or another suspend function". Call quick fix (alt + enter on OS X) menu on it — the only suggested fix will be "Make main suspend".

1. Such a suggestion is incorrect until KT-17679 fixed
2. There may be one more suggestion: implement main function through runBlocking as follows (see also KT-16085): 
fun main(args: Array<String>) = runBlocking<Unit> {
    delay(1000)
}

Create some multiplatform member, e.g. top-level field in a multiplatform project: 
// common code
expect val some: String

// platform-specific code
actual val some: String = "some"
— in common code, add a same-named member of the same type, but without expect/actual keyword, e.g. val some = "".
Now, both val some and expect val some: String are reported with an error, but each of them is reported differently, which might be confusing for a user.

For expect val some: String, there are errors for each of the targets:
[AMBIGUOUS_ACTUALS] Property 'some' has several compatible actual declarations in modules SampleIos.kt, Sample.kt
[AMBIGUOUS_ACTUALS] Property 'some' has several compatible actual declarations in modules SampleJvm.kt, Sample.kt
— it mentions modules, but points to the specific files. That's the issue, I guess there should be files in the original message.

Not sure that that's the only problem with the message, though: the same-named declaration isn't really actualisation of the expect member. Maybe we should introduce a different error message for the case, especially taking KT-32583 into consideration.

NB: if the same-named declaration has different from expect declaration type, there Is no error reporting in IDE at all, KT-25647 stands for it.
NB: reproduced on mater only.

Recently I've converted some Java files into Kotlin, and on the way I also wanted to make some code shorter.
One of the cases was of try-catch for the Cursor class on Android's SQLite API, which is recommended to be closed when not needed anymore:
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/database/Cursor

What I made is as such:

    val packageNameToAppInfo: HashMap<String, CachedAppInfo>
        @WorkerThread
        get() {
            val cursor = sDb!!.query(TableAppInfo.TABLE_NAME, null, null, null, null, null, null)
            cursor.use {
                // <- getting the cursor columns
                val whereToPut = HashMap<String, CachedAppInfo>(cursor.count)
                while (cursor.moveToNext()) {
                    // <- putting data into new object, to be inserted into the collection
                    whereToPut[cachedAppInfo.packageName!!] = cachedAppInfo
                }
                return whereToPut
            }
        }

This seems to work fine on various Android devices, but I also recently got some crashes about it, and it seems that the cause for it is that I use the use keyword, even though it should support it fine.

Weird thing is that the code itself seems that the IDE should warn about, because what should happen when it fails? It can't continue to the return part... When I try to add the code of return HashMap<String, CachedAppInfo>() after the use block, it says the code is unreachable...

The crash log is as such :

Caused by java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError: interface not implemented
       at kotlin.io.CloseableKt.closeFinally(CloseableKt.java:53)
       at com.lb.app_manager.utils.db_utils.AppInfoCacheDatabaseHandler.getPackageNameToAppInfo(AppInfoCacheDatabaseHandler.java:63)
       at com.lb.app_manager.services.AppEventService$1.doInBackground(AppEventService.java:199)
       at com.lb.app_manager.services.AppEventService$1.doInBackground(AppEventService.java:158)
       at android.os.AsyncTask$2.call(AsyncTask.java:264)
       at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask$Sync.innerRun(FutureTask.java:305)
       at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:137)
       at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1076)
       at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:569)
       at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:856)

Link:
https://console.firebase.google.com/u/0/project/app-manager-cdf2c/crashlytics/app/android:com.lb.app_manager/issues/5cd2cb46f8b88c29635ce7a7?time=last-seven-days&sessionId=5CD38716012C0001175C616C4323502A_DNE_0_v2

Looking at the code of CloseableKt, this is the problematic part, when it calls close:

@SinceKotlin("1.1")
@PublishedApi
internal fun Closeable?.closeFinally(cause: Throwable?) = when {
    this == null -> {}
    cause == null -> close()  /// <- crash here
    else ->
        try {
            close()
        } catch (closeException: Throwable) {
            cause.addSuppressed(closeException)
        }
}

If it is known to not be supported on some Android versions, the IDE should warn about using this keyword.
If it should be supported on all Android versions, it should be fixed.

Attached video showing the report, and the relevant code that made me reach this part.

Sadly, for some reason, I can't create a new emulator with this Android version (4.0.x), because when I do try it, the emulator just shows a black screen and doesn't respond to anything so I can't reproduce it. I've reported it here:
https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/132274561

Hi again. Sorry for delay.

The problem here is in missing Android Lint when Closeable function invoked on Cursor object. As we can read from https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/37047646, Closeable was added to Cursor as superinterface only in Android 4.1 so Android Studio should not allow to compile such a calls when min API level is less then 16:

class LintTest {
    fun test(cursor: Cursor) {
        val closeable: Closeable = cursor // Cast from `Cursor` to `Closeable` requires API level 16 (current min is 14)
        cursor.use {  } // no error
    }
}

Expected behavior is to get the same Lint error message for use { } as for cast.

JetBrainds does not add or modify Android Lints as they are developed by Google. Please report the issue to Android Issue Tracker

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1566395105385,"updated":0,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":false,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"KT-33461","entityId":"25-2471125","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"KT"},{"name":"summary","value":""Change access modifier" invoked on public inner Java class declaration incorrectly warns about unaccessible reference"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Kirill Likhodedov"},{"name":"created","value":"1566397917690"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"33461"},{"name":"description","value":"

Java file Outer.java:

package com.intellij.vcs.log.ui.filter;
public class Outer {
  public static class Inner {
    public Inner() {
    }
  }
}

Kotlin file KOuter.kt:

import com.intellij.vcs.log.ui.filter.Outer
class KOuter : Outer() {
  fun f(): Inner {
    return Inner()
  }
}
  1. Place the cursor at the "public" word of public static class Inner.
  2. Invoke Change access modifier -> protected
    => A warning is shown class com.intellij.vcs.log.ui.filter.Outer.Inner with protected visibility won't be accessible from file KOuter.kt
  3. Manually change "public" to "protected"
    => The code is green, compilation succeeds.

Note: it is important that the files are located in different packages.
